[h1] FRESH, VIVID, FUN & NAIVE [/h1]
[h2] –PREFACE– [/h2]
The game of my childhood which i was able to play only much later. Upon replaying it fully i analyzed each aspect and details of it, afterwards applying proper criticizm. You have to know that the game is not serious, realistic or superbly detailed, thats for do not expect much besides main gameplay content & visuals. People would not have idea how much this game influenced on me at those early days of release, but thats another talk, anyway here are my upsides and drawbacks for this vibrant hacking adventure:
[h3] - - - Drawbacks [/h3]
[olist] 
[*] Graphics would flicker on certain assumably modern gpu setups. I didn't find "natural" fix, yet i know that mods can make it. Flickering is quite annoying if the one paying attention to backgrounds, windows and some reflections. I was able to ingore it somehow though.
[*] Vehicle physics and overall driving. It might be better than in the first game, but not really enjoyable or impactful. (Not mentioning lack of garages and aircrafts)
[*] Skill system. I did not find much of a skills mandatory or really useful, but i guess it depends on a playstyle.
[*] Short length. Game includes about fifteen main missions. For me, it seemed quite quick to walkthrough in three days or so, especially if rushing. (That is what i did on a few)
[*] Story, characters and ending. Story is not bad, rather not serious and non intricate, though turn with horatios death gave me a hope for a better consequences. All characters for the exceptions of maybe marcus, wrench and couple more just mediocre, you wouldn't find anything special or connective about them, and ending just killed me, i did not feel any fulfillment when i saw last sequence..
[*] Naive. Again, you should not expect any realism or serious approach, thats for hacking, stealth, 3d printer, equipment carry, new dawn artifacts crackle, cyberdriver teaser and return of a car in perfect condition after bunch of crashes, aiden pierce appereance, and even the fact that there are only dogs from animals are all and more naive.
[*] Gameplay limit. For such a huge open world you won't do anything but exploring the world (through scoutX spots, driverSF taxi missions, collecting key data or simply steering around), missions, and maybe at the very least races n multiplayer because in-game money has no value, enough amount of skill points gained while playing main operations, non practical rare vehicles, most venues to visit only once, and poor customization (not including clothing assortment).
[/olist]
[h3] + + + Upsides [/h3]
[olist]
[*] Open world. Fresh setting of san francisco filled with alive npcs, nice views, detailed enough enviroment and humor. (Separate credit goes to yards, narrow passages and rooftops in certain locations)
[*] General and level design. It looks modern, stylish, minimal, and effective. Those dedsec ads clips, calls, news popup, map, followers, wrench etc. As of level design i really liked some building interiors and ideas like sutro tower heights, smart house, nudles area with portal alike sewer escape, satellites, blume servers, spiderbot action episode, posh penthouse etc.
[*] Private areas to infiltrate, stealth for better way of completion, intel to know what to do, RC bot and drone, essential wanted mechanic for involving escapes, best hacking in series and lastly sometimes annoying plumer puzzles. These are main gameplay aspects and they are being pleasant or signature in one way or another.
[*] Progression freedom. Though it won't give you much you can prep yourself for more pleasant further completion. 
[*] Additionally i will credit nice russian localization, references to different real life titles, factions, fast travel option, judas priest n ccr songs on a missions and pretty original side operations in face of 911, bottom dollar, pain job, ghost signals, always on and more.
[/olist]
[h2] –VERDICT– [/h2]
Well, all in all there are quite a lot of things to breakdown and tell out after beating the entire game. It is big enough, nice looking, funny, done with solid design and some entertaining gameplay elements. Despite naivety, non serious narrative, most characters, void ending, short longevity and some non so significant gameplay limits dragged the game few stages back, my rank for [b] WATCH DOGS 2 [/b] would be solid:
[h1] GOOD [/h1]
Considering the narratives around government data collection, that alone makes this a title worth playing. Plus it's just fun to play.

Beating Watch Dogs 2 on Xbox One was an absolute ride. The story is engaging, full of humor, and gives you that perfect mix of tech-savvy heist vibes with a lively San Francisco backdrop. The gameplay feels fluid, letting you hack, explore, and experiment in creative ways.

Where the game really shines for me is the multiplayer. Jumping into co-op missions and messing around with friends added hours of pure fun. The freedom to approach objectives however you like, combined with unpredictable player interactions, makes the online experience as thrilling as the single-player story.

If you enjoy open-world games with smart, flexible gameplay and a multiplayer component that actually enhances the experience, Watch Dogs 2 is a must-play.

Rating: ★★★★★★★☆☆☆ (7/10)

Watch Dogs 2 is a bold shift in tone for the franchise trading the dark, serious atmosphere of the first game for a colorful, rebellious, and youthful energy. After finishing the story and unlocking every achievement, I can say it’s a fun, creative, and much smoother experience overall, but one that sacrifices emotional depth for a lighter, more playful tone.

Story Mode

You play as Marcus Holloway, a young hacker framed by ctOS who joins DedSec to expose corruption and fight back against corporate control. The story deals with interesting modern topics like privacy, data manipulation, and social media influence.
Marcus is likeable and energetic, but both he and the DedSec crew often act too childish, cracking jokes even in serious moments. It fits the youthful vibe but takes away from the weight the story could have had.
Still, the character dynamics are great, and some missions manage to balance humor and drama nicely though I personally prefer the darker tone and maturity of Aiden Pearce’s story in the first game.

Open World

San Francisco looks amazing. It’s bright, colorful, and full of personality from the steep streets and beaches to Silicon Valley’s high tech offices and Oakland’s gritty corners. The city feels alive and distinct, and a different style unlike Chicago’s moody realism.
And unlike the first game, side missions are far less repetitive here. There’s a great variety of hacking operations, infiltration contracts, and exploration based tasks that actually feel meaningful and fun.
One of the best examples is the mission where you have to free Aiden Pearce from the Bratva (Russian Mafia) a fantastic crossover that connects both games and shows respect for the original protagonist. It’s one of the best and most memorable side missions in the game, offering a cool callback to where it all began.

Gameplay

The gameplay is the sequel’s biggest strength. Watch Dogs 2 introduces new mechanics and expanded hacking systems that make missions more dynamic. The RC Jumper and Drone completely change how you can approach objectives, and the game constantly rewards creativity.
You can complete missions entirely through stealth, or go loud with gadgets and weapons. Hacking is faster and more versatile, and the mission design encourages experimenting with multiple solutions.
Driving feels better than in the first game, with smoother controls and a more responsive feel. The game world gives you more freedom, and everything is just more fluid and fun to play.

Soundtrack & Atmosphere

The soundtrack captures the tone perfectly energetic hip hop, electronic beats, and ambient tracks that complement the colorful world. The sound design is excellent too, with city chatter, radios, and DedSec dialogue adding life to every street corner.

DLCs & Extra Content

The DLCs continue to add fun and creative content, expanding on DedSec’s missions and world. They don’t go as deep narratively, but they’re entertaining and show a little bit more of the story.

Achievements 100%

Compared to the first Watch Dogs, completing 100% of the game is much easier and more enjoyable. Collectibles are straightforward to find, the mission list feels well balanced, and the overall grind is reduced.
It’s one of those games where going for full completion feels natural rather than exhausting especially with how much variety the side missions offer this time around.

Conclusion

Watch Dogs 2 is a fun, stylish, and technically improved sequel that refines the gameplay, expands hacking mechanics, and finally makes side content worth doing. Its lighter tone, fun characters, and open world freedom make it easy to enjoy but it does lose some of the emotional depth and seriousness that defined the first game.
Marcus and the DedSec crew are entertaining, but sometimes they feel too much like kids playing rebels. For me, the first Watch Dogs still remains the best more mature, grounded, and emotionally engaging but Watch Dogs 2 deserves credit for improving the formula and making the gameplay more fluid and creative.
It’s not perfect, I also had some bugs with the shadows flickering too often and it was frustrating sometimes, but it’s definitely a good time.

Watch Dogs 2 explores the consequences of living in a hyperconnected world shaped by technology. The story unfolds through mission-based segments, each tackling themes such as social manipulation, privacy invasion, and data collection, all tied to the powerful ctOS network. The narrative doesn’t focus on a single storyline or a specific protagonist but rather on exposing the darker sides of technology while taking down the Blume Corporation.

Gameplay takes a clear step forward compared to the first title in the series. The focus now lies on personal gadgets like the Quadcopter and RC Jumper, as well as on more dynamic vehicle interaction. Cars can be hacked remotely, utility vehicles can help reach high places or transport objects, and the classic hacking abilities such as communication disruption, data theft, and citywide blackouts remain satisfying to use.

The main characters are part of the hacker collective DedSec, fighting against Blume’s technological dominance. Players control Marcus, a charismatic and skilled hacker who works alongside memorable allies like Sitara, the group’s visual designer, and Wrench, the comic relief and chaotic soul of the team, defined by his unique LED mask.

In a world where technology makes life easier, Watch Dogs 2 challenges players to question the real cost of digital convenience and the hidden motives behind constant connectivity. It serves as a reminder that technology should be a tool we control, not a system that controls us.

Watch Dogs 2 is both a reflection on our digital reality and a reminder of personal responsibility in the age of information.

[h1]Watch Dogs 2 Review[/h1]

[hr]
[h1]Overview[/h1]
If you bounced off Watch Dogs 2 because it ditched the grim tone of the first game, you are missing one of the freshest open worlds around. This is bright, stylish, and wildly playful without losing the thrill of clever hacking. This game and 1 certainly both shine in different ares but neither one falls short and offers different incredible experiences. The world sings, the tools are deeper, and the missions push you to experiment. Clear thumbs up.

[hr]
[h1]Story Overview[/h1]
You play as Marcus Holloway, a sharp Bay Area hacker flagged by ctOS 2.0 as a future criminal. After getting burned by an algorithm, he joins DedSec to expose how companies and corrupt players abuse data at scale. The crew sets out to win followers, pull off slick ops across the Bay, and humiliate powerful targets while digging into who is really pulling strings. 

[hr]
[h1]World and Atmosphere[/h1]
San Francisco and the wider Bay Area are gorgeous, dense, and alive. Color, crowds, street art, hilltop views, beaches, campuses, and tech campuses all feel hand placed. It is one of the most inviting city sandboxes I have played. Just roaming around is fun.

[hr]
[h1]Traversal[/h1]
Driving is much improved over 1. It feels responsive instead of floaty, and bikes rip through traffic nicely. Marcus also has smooth parkour, so climbing rooftops and sneaking through construction yards is clean. The RC Jumper and quadcopter change how you move, letting you scout and slip into places without even stepping inside.

[hr]
[h1]Combat[/h1]
Shooting is tighter than 1 and stealth is a blast. You can go non lethal with the stun gun and melee or bring printed weapons if you want heat. The real star is hacking during combat. Overload a fuse box, distract a guard, flip a car, lock doors, and turn defenses against enemies. Missions invite creativity instead of forcing a single route.

[hr]
[h1]Systems and Progression[/h1]
You earn followers by doing missions and side activities, which unlocks research for new hacks and gadget upgrades. 3D printers in the hackerspace let you craft weapons and tools. Builds lean toward playstyle rather than rigid classes. You can invest in drone and jumper upgrades for stealthy heists or beef up combat hacks for chaos.

[hr]
[h1]Exploration and Collectibles[/h1]
Lots to do and most of it is fun. ScoutX selfies, Key Data for research, cash stashes, paint jobs, side ops, and unique vehicles. NetHack vision makes hunting items feel purposeful instead of busywork. The city rewards curiosity with small stories tucked into alleys and offices.

[hr]
[h1]Achievements and Completion[/h1]
I 100 percented it. The list is friendly and mostly tied to exploration, missions, and trying systems. Nothing felt like grind wall material. If you already enjoy poking at the map and mixing stealth with gadgets, you will chip away at the list naturally.

[hr]
[h1]Performance and Stability[/h1]
Overall solid, but note this. On some 30 and 40 series GPUs I hit flickering shadow issues. It took trial and error and some forum hunting to squash. Keep an eye out for that. Otherwise the PC version has lots of settings, looks great in motion, and ran smoothly once dialed in. The game also goes on deep sale often, so if you are cautious, snag it discounted.

[hr]
[h1]What Works[/h1]
[list]
[*] Stunning, lively Bay Area that begs you to explore
[*] Hacking tools that encourage creativity in every mission
[*] Likeable crew and upbeat tone that fits the sandbox
[*] Better driving, cleaner shooting, and smooth stealth
[*] RC Jumper and drone open up new approaches
[/list]

[hr]
[h1]What Falls Short[/h1]
[list]
[*] Occasional PC quirks like shadow flicker on some 30/40 series GPUs
[*] A few missions feel less open than they look at first
[*] Tone shift may not land for players who want the grit of 1
[/list]

[hr]
[h1]Verdict[/h1]
Big thumbs up. If you liked the hacking in Watch Dogs 1, this is the richer, more playful version with a top tier open world and better moment to moment gameplay. Play it now if you want a creative stealth sandbox with personality. If you are on the fence, wait for a sale and dive in.

Having a retrospective of the series, I remember the first game being launched at the same time with GTA V. My parents bought Watch Dogs, after it was mentioned in a news channel. The first game was an absolute novel, the emotional story up to personal reaching to the player, his or her responsibility to maintain a prefferable level on the reputation bar, the consequences of joggling with the hacking space, trying finite, but unique number of ways to approach a mission after which you'll never get truly bored of.

All of that being thrown out the window with the sequel. The story is awful, up to cringe. Poorly written, no continuity with the first game, only grazing the mention of the characters in some missions, which would be good, if the rest of the mission would be great (even the DLC's are bad), even the main characters are poorly played and chosen in order to appeal what was trendy at the time, the idea of reputation is gone, in favour of a more GTA V'y approach, without borders and lack of important decisions (on a limited map), the missions no longer require stealth, an U100 is the jack of all trades for every mission, and the map itself is absolutely boring without visual mods, I'm glad that at every checkpoint for a mission, there is a fast travel location (I believe they thought about that and made this shunt a feature). The only simmilar thing with the first game might be the bad maneuverability of the vehicles.

For eight euros at a sale, you'll be happier if you get a sandwich or whatever. And do not even touch Watch Dogs: Legion.

After replaying Watch Dogs 1 several times, I decided to give its sequel a try. Unfortunately, it didn’t live up to my expectations.

To its credit, Watch Dogs 2 improves on hacking mechanics, offers a wider range of equipment, and brings more variety in side missions and online features. However, where it fell short for me was the main story. The first game delivered a gripping narrative and a VERY memorable protagonist, side cast, and antagonists. Watch Dogs 2 on the other hand had a central story that was very very difficult to follow and become attached to. It felt that I was just playing missions for the sake of finishing the game. The main cast didn’t stand out either. I never formed the kind of connection you’d normally expect with a protagonist. Aside from Wrench and the familiar returning face, the characters felt rather unremarkable. Furthermore, the "antagonist", if that is what you would like to call him, is also very dull and boring. 

The whole Watch Dogs 2 experience felt fairly forgettable. Personally, I do not see myself coming back to play this game at all. The fact that I replay Watch Dogs 1 every year definitely speaks volumes between the two games. I’d still recommend giving it a try, perhaps you would find it far more enjoyable than I did but I personally do not think you’d be missing out on anything particularly special. That said, this is just my personal take.

Has an NVIDIA Splash screen yet has numerous graphical issues that cannot be resolved on RTX 3000+ graphics cards. There is a Profile Inspector "fix" but it doesn't seem to be consistent, shadows still flicker all over the place. Online achievements force you to play through numerous types of garbage content that's either dead or prone to freezing. Speaking of freezing - this game is full of it, cannot complete 1 mission without having the game inexplicably freeze up requiring a task manager process kill and having to re-do whatever mission again. The performance for a game this old running on hardware that can run Cyberpunk 2077 just fine is awful, to say the least. I mean seriously, if you have textures on high the game consistently stutters both from transversal stutter and just plain loading in textures??? What is this, UE5???

In other news, the gameplay is ok (however for some reason the jumper is a downgrade from Ray's in the WD1 DLC... where did the taser go???), the story's pacing is awful and it feels like you're going all over the place doing all these various "operations", then suddenly you get cutscenes that actually advance the main plot - there's no real consistency unlike in the first game. Characters are fine but beyond the actual DedSec crew and various NPCs allied to DedSec you find in missions, everyone else is insufferable and there's no redeeming quality to any of them... Like Lenni, who you later work with and honestly she doesn't deserve that treatment. Even the "villains" who are all these various big corpo figures, just too cliche and there's never any point where it's shown you're not exactly the Second Coming of Christ (DedSec were very much neutral/antagonistic in WD1 and it shows that even despite their noble goals, they can still be harmful).

Game's fine if you want to burn away some free time but the 1st game is a superior experience.
